_metadata.description: Ancient archaeological cultures for affinity matching
_metadata.note: Cultural affiliations based on archaeological and genetic evidence

WHG.name: Western Hunter-Gatherers
WHG.description: The original post-Ice Age inhabitants of Western and Central Europe. These foragers lived in small mobile bands, hunting game and gathering wild plants for over 10,000 years before farmers arrived.
WHG.lifestyle: Hunter-gatherer bands, seasonal mobility, fishing, shellfish collection
WHG.technology: Microlithic tools, bone harpoons, bows and arrows
WHG.modern_contribution: ~10-20% of modern European ancestry, highest in Baltic and Scandinavia

EHG.name: Eastern Hunter-Gatherers
EHG.description: Hunter-gatherer populations of the eastern European forests and steppes. They were ancestral to later Steppe pastoralist cultures.

ANF.name: Anatolian Neolithic Farmers
ANF.description: The original farmers who domesticated wheat, barley, sheep, goats, and cattle in the Fertile Crescent. Their descendants spread farming across Europe starting ~9,000 years ago.
ANF.lifestyle: Settled agriculture, animal husbandry, village life
ANF.technology: Pottery, polished stone tools, sickles, granaries
ANF.modern_contribution: ~30-50% of modern European ancestry, highest in Mediterranean

EEF.name: Early European Farmers
EEF.description: Descendants of Anatolian farmers who spread across Europe, bringing agriculture. They replaced or absorbed most of the indigenous hunter-gatherers.

LBK.name: Linear Pottery Culture
LBK.description: The first farming culture of Central Europe, named for their distinctive pottery. They built longhouse villages and practiced slash-and-burn agriculture.
LBK.lifestyle: Longhouse villages, cattle herding, loess soil farming
LBK.modern_contribution: Major component of Central European ancestry

Yamnaya.name: Yamnaya/Steppe Pastoralists
Yamnaya.description: Bronze Age herders who revolutionized transportation with horses and wheeled vehicles. They massively migrated into Europe around 3000 BCE, contributing ~50% of modern Northern European ancestry. Likely spread Indo-European languages.
Yamnaya.lifestyle: Nomadic/semi-nomadic pastoralism, kurgan burials, horse domestication
Yamnaya.technology: Bronze metallurgy, wheeled wagons, horse riding
Yamnaya.modern_contribution: ~30-50% of Northern European ancestry, brought Indo-European languages

Corded_Ware.name: Corded Ware Culture
Corded_Ware.description: Descendants of Yamnaya who spread across Central and Northern Europe. Named for their cord-impressed pottery and stone battle axes. Ancestral to Germanic, Slavic, and Baltic peoples.
Corded_Ware.lifestyle: Mixed farming and herding, individual burials
Corded_Ware.modern_contribution: Major ancestor of Northern and Eastern Europeans

Bell_Beaker.name: Bell Beaker Culture
Bell_Beaker.description: A widely distributed Bronze Age culture named for their distinctive bell-shaped pottery. In Britain, Bell Beaker migrants replaced ~90% of the Neolithic population. They completed the final phase of Stonehenge.
Bell_Beaker.lifestyle: Mixed economy, individual burials with grave goods, metallurgy
Bell_Beaker.technology: Copper and early bronze working, archery
Bell_Beaker.modern_contribution: Major ancestor of Western Europeans, especially British and Irish

Celtic_IA.name: Celtic Iron Age
Celtic_IA.description: The Iron Age Celtic peoples who dominated much of Europe before Roman expansion. Their art, languages, and culture spread from Austria to Ireland.
Celtic_IA.lifestyle: Hill forts, warrior aristocracy, druids, La T√®ne art

Roman.name: Roman Empire
Roman.description: The Roman Empire unified the Mediterranean world and beyond. Rome itself was a cosmopolitan city drawing people from across three continents.

genetic_profile.note: Highly variable - Rome was genetically diverse

Anglo_Saxon.name: Anglo-Saxon
Anglo_Saxon.description: Germanic peoples (Angles, Saxons, Jutes) who migrated to Britain after Roman withdrawal. They established kingdoms that became medieval England.
Anglo_Saxon.lifestyle: Mixed farming, warrior elite, conversion to Christianity

Viking.name: Viking Age Scandinavian
Viking.description: Norse seafarers, traders, and warriors from Scandinavia who expanded across Europe and beyond. Their genetic and cultural impact stretched from Vinland to Constantinople.
Viking.modern_contribution: Major ancestor of Scandinavians, significant in British Isles

Medieval.name: Medieval European
Medieval.description: Medieval populations across Europe, representing the ancestors of most modern Europeans.

Steppe_early.name: Early Steppe
Steppe_early.description: Pre-Yamnaya steppe cultures including Sredny Stog and Khvalynsk. May have been the first to domesticate horses.

Afanasievo.name: Afanasievo
Afanasievo.description: The easternmost extension of Yamnaya-related peoples. Genetically nearly identical to Yamnaya despite being 2000km away. Possible ancestors of the Tocharian speakers.

Sintashta.name: Sintashta
Sintashta.description: Bronze Age culture known for the earliest chariots and sophisticated metallurgy. Likely Proto-Indo-Iranian speakers, ancestral to Indo-Aryan and Iranian peoples.
